application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper addresses the containment control problem of nonidentical networks with external disturbance via adaptive distributed observer method. We first present a formulation for containment error, which ensures all the followers' outputs converge to the convex hull spanned by the leaders' reference outputs. Then by using an adaptive distributed observer, the leaders' system matrices and the states of convex hull are both estimated. Furthermore, a novel global regulate equation is designed to restrain the external disturbance, and the problem of containment control for multiagent systems is solved by a dynamic output feedback approach. Finally, some simulation results are given to illustrate the validity of the theoretical results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: R ECENTLY, the coordination control has attracted the attention of more and more scholars, which has numerous applications such as vehicle formations [1], [2], target switching [3]- [5], constrained control [6], [7], switching systems [8]- [10], complex dynamical networks [11], [12], and sensor networks [13]- [16]. As one of the important issues of cooperative control, the consensus problem of multiagent systems has also been an emerging research topic [17]- [19]. The problem is also expected to expand to the area of fuzzy control [20], [21] and fault diagnosis [14]. In multiagent systems, the problem of consensus aims to design a distributed control law based on the local information so that the states or the outputs can achieve an agreement. For example, in [22] and [23], the strategy of adaptive consensus tracking control for multiagent systems has been developed based on the observer, and a neural network-based adaptive leaderfollowing consensus control has been considered for nonlinear multiagent systems in [24].

As an important research object in the control field, the multiagent systems can be roughly categorized into two classes: 1) leaderless and 2) leader-following systems. The leaderless consensus problem has been researched by a lot of researchers in the past several years. There does not exist a virtual leader in the leaderless consensus problem. Olfati-Saber and Murray [25] first studied the leaderless consensus problems for both continuous and discrete-time firstorder multiagent systems by a frequency-domain approach. Distributed event-triggered control has been considered in [26] without a leader. The necessary and the sufficient conditions were given in [27] for consensusability of linear multiagent systems, and the consensus problem of multiagent systems has been solved in [28]- [30] with different dynamics. Moreover, in the research of multiagent systems, it is also crucial to consider the presence of a leader. We call such systems leaderfollowing systems. In [31], the leader-following problem for a multiagent system has been solved with switching topologies, and distributed observers has been designed in [32] for leader-following multiagent systems. A leader-following consensus problem of a group of agents has been considered in [33] with time-varying coupling delays, and the same problem of linear multiagent systems on a switching network has also been investigated in [34]. The consensus problem of second-order leader-following has been solved in [35] by a novel distributed event-triggered sampling scheme, and the consensus problem in high-order multiagent systems has also been solved in [36] and [37]. The global cooperative control framework and observer-based consensus control against actuator faults for multiagent systems have been proposed in [38] and [39], respectively. What is more, regulation control for nonlinear systems has been considered in [40], and asymptotic output tracking of nonlinear second-order systems has been resolved by [41]. The output regulation problem [42] and tracking control [43] of multiagents have also been researched.

Inspired by the biological behavior, cooperative control for multiple leaders has received a lot of interest control has received a lot of attention from scholars as one of the research fields of multiagent systems. The difference between containment control and some multiagent systems is that there are multiple leaders in containment control. The area that the leaders surround is called the convex hull, where followers are active in this area and will not exceed the area of the convex hull. Containment control problems also have wide applications in practice, such as a group of robots moving a batch of equipment from one place to another. Some robots will carry the equipment to move, the others will provide a safe path range for the transfer robots by sensors or manual information to ensure they would not enter a dangerous area. The robots which carry equipment can be seen as the followers, and the others will be seen as the leaders. The necessary conditions and the sufficient conditions for containment control of networked systems can be studied in [44].

The distributed output containment control problem has been addressed for multiagent systems in [45] with a directed communication topology, and the dynamic output approach is also used in the containment control in this paper. Moreover, the output containment control problem is very common in practice, and the state containment control is only a special case of the dynamic output approach which is used in this paper.

In the presence of a leader without input, the leader-follower consensus problem is solved by designing a distributed adaptive consensus law which is based only on the agent dynamics and the neighboring agents' relative states in [46]. The containment control is applied in [47] to discrete-time multiagent systems with internal model compensator, and [48] presents a strict condition so that the containment problem can be solved under the distributed dynamic state feedback law, and the containment maneuvering can be applied to marine vessels in [49].
In this paper, the problem of containment control is considered for linear continuous-time multiagent systems with external disturbance via adaptive distributed observer.
The contributions of this paper are given as follows.

1) An adaptive distributed observer is used to solve containment control problem. The multiple-leader systems are both considered in this paper and [49], we further consider the disturbances in the dynamics of followers.

2) The states of systems may be unmeasurable in practice application. Therefore, a Luenburger observer is employed to estimate the unmeasurable state. Then, we use a time-varying gain matrix as the estimation of feedforward gain is which generated by the solution of regulation equations to solve the containment problem. 3) A novel global regulate equation is designed to restrain the external disturbance, and an adaptive distributed output feedback control law is designed with an estimated feedforward gain. The control law solves the containment problem without needing each follower to get the information of the leaders' matrices. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed results is illustrated by providing some simulation results.

The rest of the sections of this paper are organized as follows. We present notations, graph theory, and definitions in Section II. In Section III, we formulate the dynamic model and the problem. The main results of this paper are presented in Section IV. The numerical example is presented in Section V. The whole paper is summed up in Section VI.

Notation: Throughout this paper, let R and C denote the sets of real numbers and the complex numbers, respectively. For any x, y ∈ R n , dist(x, y) means the distance from x to y. 1 N denotes the N ×1 column vector and ⊗ denotes the Kronecker product. The identify matrix and zero matrix are described as I and 0, respectively. Let λ(A) be the eigenvalues of A, and the spectrum of a square matrix A is denoted as σ (A). (σ (A)) denotes the set of all the elements' real parts of σ (A). E,A) is described as the directed information communication networks among the agents in multiagent systems, with the set of nodes

div.head: A. Graph Theory
div.formula: A diagraph G = (V,
V = {v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N }, the set of edges E ⊆ V × V,

div.head: and a weighted adjacency matrix
div.formula: A = [a ij ] ∈ R N×N . There is an edge from v i to v j denoted as (v j , v i ) ∈ E, then a ij > 0 and else a ij = 0, and v j is the neighbor of v i . N i = {v j |(v j , v i ) ∈ E, i = j} is described as the set of neighbors of v i . A directed path means a sequence of directed edges, and a directed path is a sequence of edges (v i1 , v i2 ), (v i2 , v i3 ), . . . , (v im-1 , v im ) in a directed graph.
div.p: A directed graph is said to contain a directed spanning tree if there exists at least one agent i called the root node which has a directed path to all the other agents.

In this paper, N + M agents that consist of N followers and M leaders will be considered, and they are under a directed graph topology. The leaders' set and the followers' set are denoted by R = {v N+1 , v N+2 , . . . , v N+M } and F = {v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N }, respectively. For the N followers, there is a directed graph G = (F, E, A) represents the communication topology, where A = [a ij ] is denoted as the weighted adjacency matrix of G, L = D -A is the Laplacian matrix of G, and D = diag{ N j=1 a 1j , N j=1 a 2j , . . . , N j=1 a Nj }.

div.head: B. Definitions 1) M-Matrix:
div.p: If A is a M-matrix, then A has all eigenvalues with positive real parts, and
div.formula: A = [a ij ], a ij ≤ 0, i = j, i, j, = 1, 2, . . . , n which has the following properties. 1) A is a M-matrix. 2) A -1 ≥ 0 and A is nonsingular. 2) Convex Hull: For X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x N } is a set in V ⊆ R p ,the co(X) is called convex hull which is defined as co(X) = n i=1 α i x i |x i ∈ R p , α i ≥ 0, n i=1 α i = 1 .

div.head: III. PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: In this section, we consider N continuous-time multiagent systems with linear dynamics and M leaders, and the dynamics of ith follower are described by
div.formula: ẋi = A i x i + B i u i + N+M l=N+1 E il ω l y i = C i x i, i = 1, 2, . . . , N(1)
div.p: where x i ∈ R n and u i ∈ R u are the state and input of the ith follower, respective, and the measured output y i ∈ R p . A i , B i , E il , and C i are constant matrices with appropriate dimensions. ω l ∈ R q denoted the states of exosystems which can be seen as the tracking reference inputs or the disturbances to be rejected. The M agents assumed to be leaders as follows:
div.formula: ωl = Sω l y rl = F r ω l (2)
div.p: in which, S ∈ R q×q is a constant matrix, l = N + 1, N + 2, . . . , N + M, and y rl ∈ R p are used to be tracked which represent the reference outputs. Definition 1: Given systems (1), ( 2), and diagraph G, suppose the following two properties are satisfied, the cooperative output containment control of linear multiagent systems can be solved.
1) In the absence of external disturbances, the closedloop system can be stabilized by designing a distributed control law. 2) For any initial conditions
all the followers' outputs converge to the convex hull spanned by the leaders' reference outputs, i.e., lim
The error vectors are given as follows:
div.formula: e i = j∈N i a ij y i -y j + N+M l=N+1 a il (y i -y rl ), i = 1, 2, . . . N. (4
div.p: Let e = col(e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e N ), x = col(x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x N ), then
div.formula: e = H ⊗ I p Cx - N+M l=N+1 (H l ⊗ F r ) ωl (5) in which, C = block diag{C 1 , C 2 , . . . , C N }, H l = (1/M)L + A 0l , A 0l = diag{a 1l , a 2l , . . . , a Nl }, and H = N+M l=N+1 H l , ωl = 1 N ⊗ ω l .
div.p: By the proof of [47, Lemma 1], H is an M-matrix. The basic lemma can be given as follows.

Lemma 1 [48]: For the continuous-time multiagent systems (1) and leaders (2), lim t→∞ e = 0 implies that the convergence of the outputs to the convex hull spanned by the tracking outputs as time t tends to infinity.
According to the Lemma 1, we can get if lim t→∞ e i = 0, then
div.formula: lim t→∞ C i x i = lim t→∞ N+M l=N+1 ζ il F r ω l , i = 1, 2, . . . , N. (6) in which, ζ il ∈ R is the ith row element of ζ l = H -1 H l 1 N .
div.p: To solve the problem of the output containment control with adaptive distributed observer, we need the following assumptions.
Assumption 1: The graph G has a spanning tree with at least one leader v l ∈ R as its root.
Assumption 2:
div.formula: (A i , B i ) is stabilizable and (C i , A i ) is detectable.
div.p: Assumption 3: All the eigenvalues of S have no negative real parts.
The distributed observer was first developed in [50] and [51] with a different network topology structure for the leader, and the dynamic compensator in [48] is as follows:
div.formula: ηi = Sη i + μ ⎛ ⎝ j∈N i a ij η i -η j + N+M l=N+1 a il (η i -ω l ) ⎞ ⎠ (7)
div.p: where η i ∈ R q , i = 1, 2, . . . , N, and μ < 0.

However, the matrix S in (7) can not be accessed by all the followers. In other words, each follower in (7) tries to use the matrix S, which may not work in practice. Then, we use an adaptive distributed observer for S which takes the following form:
div.formula: Ṡi = μ 1 ⎛ ⎝ j∈N i a ij (S i -S j ) + N+M l=N+1 a il (S i -S) ⎞ ⎠(8)
div.p: where S i ∈ R q , i = 1, 2, . . . , N, μ 1 < 0. Under the Assumptions 1 and 3, for i = 1, 2, . . . , N, lim t→∞ (S i (t)-S) = 0, and S i is the estimation of S. From ( 8), it can be known that only the followers which can access the leaders know the matrix S. Thus, the adaptive distributed observer is more realistic than the distributed observer.
Remark 1: The adaptive observer was used to solve the problem of cooperative output regulation in [52]. In this paper, we extend the adaptive observer to multiagent systems with multiple leaders.
Lemma 2: Given the systems ( 2) and ( 8), let Si = S i -S. For any initial condition, we have, for any μ 1 < 0 and i = 1, 2, . . . , N, lim t→∞ Si (t) = 0 exponentially.
Proof: From (8), it can be seen that Ṡi = μ 1 ( j∈N i a ij (S i -S j ) + N+M l=N+1 a il (S i -S)), and we have
div.formula: Ṡi = Ṡi -Ṡ = Ṡi = μ 1 ⎛ ⎝ j∈N i a ij (S i -S j ) + N+M l=N+1 a il (S i -S) ⎞ ⎠ = μ 1 ⎛ ⎝ j∈N i a ij ( Si -Sj ) + N+M l=N+1 a il Si ⎞ ⎠ . (9
) Let S = ( ST 1 , ST 2 , . . . , ST N ) T , then (9) can be written in the form of Ṡ = μ 1 N+M l=N+1 (H l ⊗ I q ) S = μ 1 (H ⊗ I q ) S.
div.p: Based on the property of M-matrix, all the eigenvalues of H have positive real parts, and μ 1 < 0. Therefore, lim t→∞ S(t) = 0 exponentially, and for i = 1, 2, . . . , N, lim t→∞ Si (t) = 0 exponentially.

div.head: IV. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: We will research output containment control of continuoustime linear multiagent systems, and design an output feedback controller in this section.
Lemma 3 [52]: Consider the following system:
where x ∈ R n , F ∈ R n×n is Hurwitz, > 0, F 1 (t) ∈ R n×n , and F 2 (t) ∈ R n are bounded and continuous for all t ≥ t 0 . We have: 1) if F 1 (t), F 2 (t) → 0 as t → ∞(exponentially), then, for any

x(t 0 ) and any > 0, x(t) → 0 as t → ∞(exponentially) and 2) if F 1 (t) = 0, F 2 (t) decays to zero exponentially at the rate of α, and > (α/α F ), where α F = min( (σ (-F))), then, for any x(t 0 ), x(t) → 0 as t → ∞ exponentially at the rate of α. From ( 7) and ( 8), we can know an observer with the state η i ∈ R q for the ith follower change from (7) to the following form:

div.p: Using the property of the Kronecker product, (

div.p: where Sd = S d -I N ⊗ S = block diag{ S1 , S2 , . . . , SN }. Under the Assumption 3, for μ 1 , μ 2 < 0, the matrix (I N ⊗ S) + μ 2 (H ⊗ I q ) is Hurwitz, and by lim t→∞ Si (t) = 0 exponentially, lim t→∞ Sd (t) = 0 exponentially. Thus, we can know lim t→∞ ηi (t) = 0 exponentially by Lemma 3.
In multiagent systems, some agents can only get information from their neighbors directly. We design the following dynamic output feedback control law:
div.formula: ξi = A i ξ i + B i u i + N+M l=N+1 E il ω l + L i (C i ξ i -C i x i ) u i = K 1i ξ i + K 2i (t)η i , i = 1, 2, . . . , N. (15

div.formula: u i = K 1i ξ i + K * 2i η i + (K 2i (t) -K * 2i
div.p: )η i , and based on (1), ( 15), the closed-loop dynamics can be written as
div.formula: ẋi = A i x i + B i K 1i ξ i + B i K * 2i η i + B i K 2i (t) -K * 2i η i + N+M l=N+1 E il ω l ξi = A i ξ i + B i K 1i ξ i + B i K * 2i η i + B i K 2i (t) -K * 2i η i + N+M l=N+1 E il ω l + L i (C i ξ i -C i x i ) (16) in which A = block diag{A 1 , A 2 , . . . , A N }, B = block diag{B 1 , B 2 , . . . , B N }, C = block diag{C 1 , C 2 , . . . , C N }, and E l = block diag{E 1l , E 2l , . . . , E Nl }. div.p: However, since the matrix S can not be accessed by all the followers, the solution of regulation equations can not be calculated. By the [52, Lemmas 3 and 4], we can solve the problem.
Remark 2: In [52], the adaptive problem of the regulation equations has already been solved, and K 2i (t) can be obtained directly. But it is also needed to calculate K * 2i , so we let

div.p: cl , and X 12 cl = X 22 cl . By simple calculation, we can get the value of K * 2 . Theorem 1: Suppose that Assumptions 1-3 hold. Then, the containment control problem of multiagent systems (1) and exosystems (2) can be solved by the distributed output controller (15), where K 1i , L i , be such that
div.formula: (A i +B i K 1i ), (A i +L i C i ) are stable and lim t→∞ K 2i (t) -K * 2i = 0.
div.p: Proof: Let T = I 0 -I I , and Āc = TA c T -1 , such that
div.formula: TA c T -1 = A + BK 1 BK 1 0 A + LC . From Assumptions 2 we know Āc is Hurwitz, equivalently, A c is Hurwitz. Let xc = x c -N+M l=N+1 X cl v l , then we obtain ẋc = ẋc - N+M l=N+1 X cl vl = A c x c + N+M l=N+1 B cl v l + δ 1 (t) - N+M l=N+1 X cl (I N ⊗ S) ωl 1 = A c x c + N+M l=N+1 B cl v l + δ 1 (t) - N+M l=N+1 X cl (I N ⊗ S) ωl 2 - N+M l=N+1 X cl 0 Sd = A c x c + N+M l=N+1 B cl v l - N+M l=N+1 X cl (I N ⊗ S) ωl (I N ⊗ S)η + μ 2 H ⊗ I q η + δ 2 (t) = A c x c + N+M l=N+1 B cl v l - N+M l=N+1 X cl (I 2N ⊗ S)v l - N+M l=N+1 X cl 0 μ 2 H ⊗ I q η + δ 2 (t)(20)

div.p: in which

div.p: And lim t→∞ Sd = 0, lim t→∞ K 2i (t) -K * 2i = 0, so it easy to see that lim t→∞ δ 2 (t) = 0. Where lim t→∞ ηi = 0, then by Lemma 3 lim t→∞ xc = 0.
From (5), we can obtain the following form of e:
div.formula: e = H ⊗ I p Cx -H ⊗ I p (I N ⊗ F r )η + H ⊗ I p × (I N ⊗ F r )η - N+M l=N+1 (H l ⊗ F r ) ωl = H ⊗ I p ẽ + (H ⊗ F r ) ⎛ ⎝ η - N+M l=N+1 (H l ⊗ F r ) ωl ⎞ ⎠ = H ⊗ I p ẽ + (H ⊗ F r ) η(22)
div.p: by Lemma 4, lim t→∞ η = 0, so lim t→∞ ẽ = 0 means lim t→∞ e = 0. The error ẽ can be written as
div.formula: ẽ = Cx -(I N ⊗ F r )η = C c x c - N+M l=N+1 0 I N ⊗ 1 M F r v l = C c x c - N+M l=N+1 D cl v l = C c xc + N+M l=N+1 C c X cl v l - N+M l=N+1 D cl v l(23)
div.p: by ( 19), ẽ = C c xc , and lim t→∞ xc = 0. Thus, lim t→∞ ẽ = 0, and lim t→∞ e = 0. The containment control problem of multiagent systems is solved and the proof is completed. Remark 3: By the study from [47] and [48], the containment problem has been solved based on strict linear matrix equations conditions and internal model compensator, respectively. In this paper, we should further consider how to solve the problem of the estimation of K 2i (t).

Remark 4: Compared with [48], it may not be realistic to acquire the states of systems in practical application, we use output feedback approach to solve the containment problem in this paper, and the disturbances are also considered in systems to ensure more application value. What is more, different from the distributed observer in [48], we further use the adaptive distributed observer which can estimate the information of leaders' matrices for the followers who can not access S. Remark 5:
div.formula: Let ϕ i = ξ i -x i , then we have φi = ξi -ẋi = A i ξ i + B i u i + N+M l=N+1 E il ω l + L i (C i ξ i -C i x i ) - ⎛ ⎝ A i x i + B i u i + N+M l=N+1 E il ω l ⎞ ⎠ = (A i + L i C i )ϕ i .
div.p: Under Assumption 2, (C i , A i ) is detectable, then there exist appropriate main matrices L i , such that lim t→∞ ϕ i = 0. By the above proof, the observers ξ i in (15) can estimate the unmeasurable states x i , i = 1, 2, . . . , N. The unmeasurable states x i and observers ξ i have the same dimension n, so the observers ξ i can be also seen as full order observers. Remark 6: Multiagent systems with signal leader can be seen as a special form of multiple leaders' multiagent systems. When the leader is only one, it can be seen that the convex hull which is formed by the leaders in multiple leaders' multiagent systems is as a point, and the outputs trajectories of the followers converge to the trajectory of the leader. Thus the problem becomes the leader-following problem.

div.head: V. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we provide two simulation examples, and we use the same topology structure in examples. The approach designed in Section IV to solve the problem of containment control is considered with six agents under the directed graph shown in Fig. 1. The nodes 1-4 are denoted as followers, the nodes 5 and 6 are denoted as leaders. The Laplcian matrix is as follows:
and H 5 and H 6 are written as

div.head: A. Example I
div.p: In this example, we choose M = 2 and the systems of leaders are given as the following form: Next, we consider the systems of followers with N = 4
div.formula: ẋi1 = x i2 + u 2l ẋi2 = u 1l + 0.05ω 1l + 0.1ω 3l y i = 0.1x i1 where x i = x i1 x i2 ∈ R 2 is
div.p: Finally, we provide two figures for validating the results of Example I. One is about the outputs of leaders and followers, we need to ensure that the trajectories of followers are not exceeding the range formed by the leaders, another is about the distributed containment error.
As shown in Fig. 2, the red lines represent the reference outputs, and the blue lines represent the outputs of followers.

However, another purpose of this paper is to make all the followers' outputs converge to the convex hull spanned by the reference outputs of leaders. The results of simulation diagram can reflect the purpose directly.
Then, as shown in Fig. 3, the time history of the containment error for Example I can be reflected with different initial

div.head: B. Example II
div.p: The matrices for the followers are shown as follows: follows:
In Fig. 4, all the followers' outputs converge to the convex hull spanned by the reference outputs of leaders, and the containment errors are shown in Fig. 5 for Example II.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the cooperative robust containment control problem for linear continuous-time multiagent systems has IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS been solved by using an adaptive distributed observer. The problem of the estimation of gain matrix in control law has been solved. We has also designed a distributed compensator under the output feedback controller, such that all the followers' outputs converge to the convex hull spanned by the leaders' references output. Some simulation results are provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed results.
